cblnsrch_test.cpp

Does a cubic line search, i.e. given a nonlinear function, a starting point and a direction, a new point is calculated where the function has decreased "sufficiently". The line search algorithms are based on the Newton method of approximating root values of monotone decreasing functions. When the derivative of the function at a starting point on the X-axis can be calculated, the intersection of the tangent at point (with gradient ) with the X-axis can be used to get a better approximation of the minima at .

This function is based on this idea: Given a nonlinear function , a n-dimensional starting point and a direction (known as Newton direction), a new point is calculated as

in a way that has decreased sufficiently. Sufficiently means that

where is a fraction of the initial rate of decrease .

This function can be used for minimization or solving a set of nonlinear equations of the form . Finding the root value (the x-value at which the related function will intersect the X-axis) will then solve the equations. In contrast to line search (lnsrch.cpp) the cubic line search interpolates four points to find the minimum value and is useful, when gradient information is already available or when more than three function evaluations have been calculated.

Parameters:
xold n-dimensional starting point.
fold The value of function func at point xold.
g The n-dimensional gradient of function func at point xold.
p n-dimensional point to specify the search direction (the Newton direction).
x New n-dimensional point along the direction p from xold where the function func decreases "sufficiently".
f The new function value for point x.
func Function to decrease.
lambda Controls the accuracy of line search, is a good choice.
Returns:
none.
Please follow the link to view the source code of the example. The example can be executed in the example directory of package LinAlg.

Author:
M. Kreutz
Date:
1998
Changes
none
Status
stable

lnsrch.cpp
00001 //===========================================================================
00051 //===========================================================================
00052 #include <iostream>
00053 #include "Array/ArrayIo.h"
00054 #include "LinAlg/arrayoptimize.h"
00055 
00056 
00057 using namespace std;
00058 
00059 
00060 // Function to be decreased:
00061 //
00062 double my_func(const Array< double > &x)
00063 {
00064     return x(0) * x(0) + 2;
00065 }
00066  
00067 
00068 // Derivative function:
00069 //
00070 double gradient(double x)
00071 {
00072     return 2*x;
00073 }
00074 
00075  
00076 int main()
00077 {
00078     Array< double > x_old(1),       // old point
00079                     x_new(1),       // new point
00080                     p(1),           // Newton direction 
00081                     grad(1);        // gradient of function at old point
00082     double          f_old(0.),      // function-value of old point 
00083                     f_new(0.),      // function-value of new point
00084                     lambda(0.25);   // accuracy of line search
00085     unsigned        i;              // number of "cblnsrch" iterations
00086 
00087  
00088     // input points for "my_func":
00089     //
00090     double x_values[8] = 
00091     {
00092         -4., -3., -2., -1.,  
00093          0.,  1.,  2.,  3.
00094     };
00095  
00096     // Initialize values for first call of "cblnsrch":
00097     //
00098     x_old(0) = x_values[0];       // starting point is -4.0 
00099     f_old = my_func(x_old);       // Calculate function value of starting point
00100     grad(0) = gradient(x_old(0)); // Calculate gradient of starting point
00101     p(0) = 3.;                    // decrease function by going to
00102                                   // the "right" on the X-axis.
00103     x_new(0) = x_old(0);          // No new values calculated yet 
00104     f_new = f_old;
00105 
00106 
00107     std::cout << "Performing cubic line search for function f(x) = x*x + 2 "
00108               << "with starting point (-4, 18) and direction (3, 11):" 
00109               << endl << endl;
00110  
00111     // Head for output of results:
00112     std::cout << "new point:\tfunction-value:\n";
00113     std::cout << "-------------------------------\n";
00114 
00115     // Presettings for formatted output:
00116     std::cout.setf(ios::fixed | ios::right | ios::internal | ios::showpos);
00117     std::cout.precision(2);
00118     std::cout.width(5);
00119  
00120     // Output of starting values:
00121     std::cout << x_new(0) << "\t\t" << f_new << endl;     
00122  
00123     // Take 5 "cblnsrch" iterations:
00124     for (i = 0; i < 5; i++) 
00125     {
00126         // Calculate next new point:
00127         cblnsrch(x_old, f_old, grad, p, x_new, f_new,my_func, lambda);
00128  
00129         // Output of calculated results:
00130         std::cout << x_new(0) << "\t\t" << f_new << endl;     
00131  
00132         // Setting values for next iteration:
00133         x_old(0) = x_new(0);
00134         f_old = f_new;
00135         grad(0) = gradient(x_old(0));
00136     }
00137 
00138     return 0;
00139 }
